div.head: Section 2
div.p: From the preceding we can draw three conclusions. The first is that those who wish to bury their riches or treasures with themselves or with their own bodies intend a great interest, namely: honors, praise, and glory, which are the effects of honor and parts of happiness according to the Philosopher in Rhetoric I, and through these to live perpetually in the opinions of men. And they hope to achieve this if their status, riches, opulence, sublime works, and magnificence, such as they were, should be made known to posterity.

For praise is an encomium celebrated by the mouth of another, or praise is discourse elucidating the magnitude of virtue according to Saint Thomas on the Psalms, and
the Philosopher in Rhetoric I :
praise is speech showing the magnitude of virtue .

But glory is frequent fame about someone with praise according to
Cicero in his Rhetoric . And as he himself says in his oration for M. Marcellus:
It is the illustrious and promulgated fame of merits, either toward one's citizens or toward one's country or toward the whole human race . Or according to Augustine:
it is the judgment of men thinking well about people .

The proposition is proved first because the desire for praise, honor, and glory is naturally in men, whence it is frequent and daily, so that there is no one who does not desire it. Indeed Valerius says in book 8:
no one is so humble and of such abject condition whom the sweetness of glory does not soften and touch . And Cicero in the Tusculans :
honor nourishes the arts and we are all inflamed to the pursuit of glory and praise ; and in De Officiis I :
one will scarcely find anyone who, when labors and dangers are added, does not desire as if a reward for things done, beyond this glory and praise . And in his book of orations he says there is nothing in life to be greatly sought except praise and honor. But in pursuing it, all tortures of the body, all dangers of death and exile should be considered of little importance. Indeed because, as
Gregory says in book 6 chapter 209 of the Register:
just as fire blown by wind becomes greater, so the endeavors of good minds profit by commendation . Hence the emperors and ancient kings, considering this inclination or condition of mortals, in order to encourage virtuous citizens to undertake labors especially for the republic and to act strenuously in all things according to virtue, acted in three ways according to Albert the Great on Ethics I. And here they showed by rewarding the well-deserving with that praise, namely that they would be displayed in glory so that they might receive titles of praise, and they made an eternal memorial of them sitting upon snow-white horses (as Titus Livius says), which belonged to the king's chair, surrounded everywhere by a herald crying with public voice and setting forth their virtues and the works of their virtues by which they had merited this. And this does not differ much from what King Ahasuerus did concerning Mordecai whom he ordered to ascend a horse that belonged to the king's chair, dressed in the king's garments, and received the royal crown and to be led through the city square with Haman crying out: Thus shall it be done to the man whom the king desires to honor . Esther 6.
And secondly, they also had titles inscribed in the temple and hall, so that even when they were not present, their virtue might be known.

Thirdly, they also received memorials in statues and arches, so that even after their death that virtue might not be destroyed by oblivion. On account of which victors are still found depicted with round shields tied to the back of the head, so that on the shield it might be seen how strenuously they fought for the republic. For a shield is cut where it receives the blows of the enemy, and therefore a soldier protected by a shield crowned signifies that he strenuously withstood the assaults and blows of enemies. Hence it is that in temples the heads of gods and saints are painted in circular form in the manner of a shield fitted to the back of the head. Therefore such praises are rewards of virtue, etc. Thus Albert.

Behold how greatly the ancients valued honor, praise, and glory, not only for the praise of those present, but rather they intended that their virtue, opulence, greatness of status, and works strenuously done by them might be established for future ages, so that thus they might live, as was possible, eternally. And this was a great interest to them.
Therefore, since, through the placing of those treasures in tombs, they intended praise, honor, and glory, to which men are naturally inclined, by which they strove to acquire a great interest.

Secondly, the proposition is proved: the desire for living forever is naturally in all mortals, as is clear in Ethics X, the reason for which can be assigned because, according to the same Philosopher in De Anima II, all created things according to the nature and condition of each desire to participate in divine being, and for its sake they do whatever they do according to nature. And yet since they had learned from experience that it would be impossible to live forever in that mode of living which is somewhat similar to the eternal, namely in the memory and opinion of men, they were content. And therefore in this mortal life they worked certain outstanding things according to the inclination, strength, power, or riches of each, so that they might provide material to coming men (when they themselves had been removed by death) for thinking well of them, revering them, and praising and exalting them, so that thus they might live in a certain way eternally. Therefore through the fact that most noble kings and powerful men ordered such treasures to be stored with them in their tombs, they strove to claim for themselves honor, good opinion, fame, praise, and glory, and thus a great interest.

Moreover, among other things which the ancients were accustomed to care for in order to achieve perpetual memory of men, praise, etc., through death (which custom endures to this day), this was one and not less principal: namely that arms or insignia, which were substituted in place of images, were placed in temples or in tombs, walls, or arches and other solemn buildings, so that they might be manifest to all and henceforth they might have knowledge of whose or of whom they had been and might begin to revere them. This is touched upon in
l. 1, §. casum, ff. de postulando . This also appears
in 1 Maccabees chapter 13 where it is read of Simon Maccabee that
he built a tomb for his father and his brothers, a building high to see, of polished stone behind and before .
And he set up seven pyramids, one opposite another, for father and mother and four brothers, and around these he placed great columns, and upon the columns arms for eternal memory.

And next to the arms, sculpted ships which would be seen by men sailing the sea.
Thus far that passage. And 1 Kings 13:
the Philistines placed the arms of the slain Saul in the temple of Ashtaroth, but his body they hung on the wall of Beth-shan .

Finally in Song of Songs 4, Solomon mentions that King David his father had made a tower from which
hung a thousand shields, all the armor of the strong ,
which perhaps were the insignia and arms of a thousand nobles, both of parents and of friends or subjects to him, which he placed on a thousand shields hanging from the said tower.

Pliny also in book 35 chapter 3 relates that certain ancient Romans, leaving shields, arms or bucklers for the perpetual memory of their own, did the same. For Appius Claudius, who was consul with Servilius, first established the custom of privately dedicating shields of his family in a sacred or public place. For he placed in the temple of Bellona his ancestors, and it pleased him that they be viewed on high and that the titles of honors be read.
A beautiful thing indeed if a crowd of children with small images, or some offspring equally displayed. Such shields everyone views with joy and favor.

After him Marcus Aemilius, colleague in the consulship of Q. Lutatius, placed them not only in the Aemilian basilica but also in his own home. By Marcius's example, the Carthaginians also made shields and images of gold and carried them with them in camps, etc. Thus Pliny.

And it should be known that in ancient times it was the custom at Rome that images of ancestors be carried in funerals and in tombs to show gentility, that is, genealogy, and in the atria there were images that would be viewed, expressed faces were arranged in individual shrines so that there might be images that would accompany family funerals. Others were affixed at doors and around the threshold, images of great souls with the spoils of enemies attached, which not even a buyer would be permitted to break, and which even when masters changed were ornaments of the house according to the same Pliny in the book quoted above, chapter 2. Therefore in place of images arms or insignia were substituted (as we said), and Budaeus thinks that later times had family insignia instead of images, which are commonly called arms,
which themselves also at first, as is likely, were rewards of virtue and honors of deeds excellently done. If you wish to see more of these to satiety, read
Casaneus in the first part, conclusion 10, in the Catalogue of the Glory of the World . It is clear therefore that among the ancients, just as is done now among the moderns, for the sake of honor and praise and good opinion and fame, either of their own persons or of their ancestors or of the antiquity of the origin of their family or gentility and nobility, there was great care and the highest study in the judgment of perpetual memory among men.

What, I ask, do we now see also among Catholics, especially noble men indeed powerful and great in riches, kings and magnates, except to place banners, insignia, shields and arms either golden or gilded or silver or iron in chapels at churches erected by themselves with great study and at great expense; moreover to raise tombs or mounds in them as high as they can; and also to adorn them with silk or gold-woven coverings and many such kinds of precious furnishings. And this indeed for no other reason than for the sake of honor and perpetual fame. But because burying treasures and precious furnishings with the bodies of lords manifested their glory, nobility, riches, excellence of status and eminence, thence a motive and material was given to those seeing and hearing to revere them, value them greatly, and also to praise and magnify them, and all other things looking to honor and glory. Therefore those who ordered their riches and treasures to be placed with them in their tombs intended a great interest, namely perpetual honor and things looking to honor.

For the interest of honor is greater than any other interest. For as Cicero says in De Amicitia:
Where will you find someone who would place the honor of a friend before his own? . And Aristotle in the Economics:
Someone bears it much more grievously if he is deprived of his honor than if his goods are taken from him . And such earthly honors are desired more than heavenly ones.
De renuntiatione. C. nisi cum pridem § pro graui . And for the sake of sustaining honor, action must also be brought for injuries, as
Baldus says in L. observare § antequam ff. de officio proconsulis . Indeed, for the protection and defense of one's own honor, a duel and war can be initiated by law against those injuring or detracting from our honor.
Baldus in cap. circa principium et columna de pace tenenda. in de feudis
because no one is bound to suffer injury or small consideration of his own honor
argumentum ff. de postulando in principio . Indeed, he is cruel who neglects his own reputation.
c. nolo 12 q. 122 . Hence it is said that the causes of life and honor are equated
l. Iusta, ff. de manumissionibus . And so someone can kill an assailant in defense of his honor just as for the defense of his person, as per the doctors in
l. 1. Codex, Unde ui.
and through
Jason in l. vt vim ff de Iustitia et iure
and
Petrus Gerardus in his Singula singulum 33 . Whence the text in
l. miles, § socer de adulteriis :
It is shameful to leave one's honor unavenged. For honor cannot be estimated by monetary price, as
Baldus says in the chapter De vita et honestate clericorum
and in
the chapter ex tenore column 2 de appellationibus . And what is more, honor brings utility
l. si longius, at the end, ff, de iudiciis , and wherever there is a question of honor, it is said to be an arduous cause in
l. si inimicitie at the end ff de his quibus ut indignis . Thence moreover it is that what cannot be done without honor being preserved cannot be done, thus the text has in
l. in eadem causa ff ex quibus causis maiores .
Gerardus notes in Singula, singulum.
And thus concerning the first proposition.
